tooltip.title: Glycan ID
tooltip.text: Unique accessions assigned to the registered glycan structures in GlyTouCan database. You can search Glycan ID by single or multiple comma-separated GlyTouCan Accession(s) or Cross Reference(s) ID.

tooltip.title: Glycan ID
tooltip.text: You can search Glycan ID by single or multiple comma-separated GlyTouCan Accession(s) or Cross Reference(s) ID. By selecting 'Exact match' only glycans with the provided IDs will be found. When selecting 'Related Glycans' also glycans that have the same structure but more structural information and glycans with less structural information (up to compositions) will be included in the search result.

tooltip.title: Glycan ID Namespace
tooltip.text: Click to select a Glycan ID Namespace.

tooltip.title: Monoisotopic Mass
tooltip.text: The monoisotopic mass is the sum of the masses of the atoms in a molecule. Use the sliders to select a Monoisotopic Mass range for your glycan(s).

tooltip.title: Permethylated Mass
tooltip.text: The Permethylated Mass is the sum of the masses of the atoms in a molecule. Use the sliders to select a Monoisotopic Mass range for your glycan(s).

tooltip.title: No of Sugars
tooltip.text: Use the sliders to select Number of Sugars range for your glycan(s).

tooltip.title: Glycoproteins
tooltip.text: how many glycoproteins Glycoproteins

tooltip.title: Enzymes
tooltip.text: How Many Enzymes are on glycan

tooltip.title: Organism
tooltip.text: Search for glycan(s) that can be made by an Organism. It is possible to specify multiple organisms and combine the search results. If 'Or' is selected the search result will be a union of all glycans made in any of the organisms. If 'AND' is selected only glycans that are present in each of organisms will be included in the result set. If 'Annotated' is selected only glycans with the organism annotation coming from one of the source databases will be included. If 'Infered' is selected, in addition to the glycans with the annotation also glycans that received the annotation because they are related will be included. For example: the composition of glycan X will also receive the organism annotation from glycan X. However the composition will only be included if 'Infered' is selected.

tooltip.title: Glycan Image
tooltip.text: its an image

tooltip.title: Glycan Type
tooltip.text: The classification of glycan based on the nature of the sugar–peptide bond and the oligosaccharide attached. Click to select a Glycan Type.

tooltip.title: Glycan Subtype
tooltip.text: Subclassifcation of Glycan types. Click to select a Glycan Subtype.

tooltip.title: Glycosylated Protein
tooltip.text: A unique identifier assigned to a isoform chosen to be the canonical sequence in UniProt database. Enter the UniProtKB Accession for a  protein that bears your glycan.

tooltip.title: Binding Protein
tooltip.text: Search for all glycans that have been reported to bind to a protein. The UniProtKB accession is used to identify the protein.

tooltip.title: Glycan Motif
tooltip.text: A “motif” refers to a substructure that appears in multiple glycans including O and N glycans. Enter a Glycan Motif comprising part of your glycan(s).

tooltip.title: Glycan Name
tooltip.text: Click to select Glycan Name.

tooltip.title: Biosynthetic Enzyme
tooltip.text: Biosynthetic enzymes are enzymes involved in metabolism pathways that convert and modify simple compounds to complex coumpounds and macromolecules. Enter the Gene Name of an enzyme that particpates in the biosynthesis of your glycan(s).

tooltip.title: subsumption
tooltip.text: subsumption are enzymes involved in metabolism pathways that convert and modify simple compounds to complex coumpounds and macromolecules. Enter the Gene Name of an enzyme that particpates in the biosynthesis of your glycan(s).

tooltip.title: Pubmed ID
tooltip.text: A PMID is the unique identifier number used in PubMed for each article. The PMID is assigned to each article record when it enters the PubMed system.

tooltip.title: InCHI Key
tooltip.text: A InCHI Key is the unique identifier number used in InCHI Key for each article.

tooltip.title: IUPAC
tooltip.text: A IUPAC  is the unique identifier number used in IUPAC Key for each article.

tooltip.title: WURCS
tooltip.text: A WURCS  is the unique identifier number used in WURCS Key for each article.

tooltip.title: GlycoCT
tooltip.text: A GlycoCT  is the unique identifier number used in GlycoCT Key for each article.

tooltip.title: GLYCAM IUPAC
tooltip.text: A GLYCAM IUPAC  is the unique identifier number used in GLYCAM IUPAC Key for each article.

tooltip.title: Byonic™
tooltip.text: A Byonic™ is the unique identifier number used in Byonic™ Key for each article.

tooltip.title: Isomeric SMILES
tooltip.text: A Isomeric SMILES  is the unique identifier number used in Isomeric SMILES Key for each article.

tooltip.title: Other
tooltip.text: Other

unmapped.title: Reason why certain entries could not be found

tooltip.title: Sequence
tooltip.text: GlycoCT/WURCS sequence of Glycan.

tooltip.title: Sequence Type
tooltip.text: Select GlycoCT or WURCS sequence Type.

tooltip.title: Composition Search Template List
tooltip.text: Select composition template and click on load to pre-fill template composition values.

mass.text: Find all glycans with the same mass.

mass_pme.text: Find all glycans with the same permethylated mass.

composition.text: Find all glycans with the same composition.

glycan_type.text: Find all glycans with the same type/subtype.

organism.text: Find all glycans with the same organism.

pmid.text: Find all glycans with the same PMID.

tooltip.title: UniProtKB Accession
tooltip.text: You can search UniProtKB Accession by single or multiple comma-separated UniProtKB Accession(s). Accession assigned to the protein isoform chosen to be the canonical sequence to which all positional annotation refers in UniProtKB database.

tooltip.title: Position
tooltip.text: You can search site by entering annotation Position.

tooltip.title: Gene Name
tooltip.text: Name/Symbol of the gene officially assigned by the Gene Nomenclature Committees (HGNC, ICSGNM, RGNC etc). Enter the Name of the Gene encoding your protein.

tooltip.title: Gene Name
tooltip.text: Name/Symbol of the gene officially assigned by the Gene Nomenclature Committees (HGNC, ICSGNM, RGNC etc). Enter the Name of the Gene encoding your protein.

tooltip.title: UniProt Name
tooltip.text: Name/Symbol of the gene officially assigned by the Gene Nomenclature Committees (HGNC, ICSGNM, RGNC etc). Enter the Name of the Gene encoding your protein.

tooltip.title: Glycosylation Type
tooltip.text: Click to select Glycosylation Type.

tooltip.title: Glycosylation Subtype
tooltip.text: Click to select Glycosylation Subtype.

tooltip.title: Pubmed ID
tooltip.text: A PMID is the unique identifier number used in PubMed for each article. The PMID is assigned to each article record when it enters the PubMed system.

tooltip.title: GO Name
tooltip.text: Gene ontology is a precisely defined, common controlled vocabulary for describing the roles of genes and gene products in any organism and includes three categories: Molecular function, Biological process, and Cellular component. GO Name - term name, which may be a word or string of words. GO ID - a unique alphanumeric identifier.

tooltip.title: GO ID
tooltip.text: Gene ontology is a precisely defined, common controlled vocabulary for describing the roles of genes and gene products in any organism and includes three categories: Molecular function, Biological process, and Cellular component. GO Name - term name, which may be a word or string of words. GO ID - a unique alphanumeric identifier.

tooltip.title: Covalently Attached Glycan
tooltip.text: Search for proteins that have a certain glycan covalently attached (e.g. glycosylation or glycation). The glycan has to be specified by a GlyTouCan accession number.

tooltip.title: Bound Glycan
tooltip.text: Search for proteins that bind a certain glycan. The glycan is specified by a GlyTouCan accession number.

tooltip.title: Glycosylated Amino Acid
tooltip.text: Amino acids are organic compounds containing amine (-NH2) and carboxyl (-COOH) functional groups, along with a side chain (R group) specific to each amino acid. Click to highlight multiple selections for Glycosylated Amino Acid.

tooltip.title: Protein or Peptide Sequence
tooltip.text: The sequence of the amino acids of the protein or peptide. Click to select Sequence Type and enter a Protein or Peptide Sequence.

tooltip.title: Pathway ID
tooltip.text: A biological pathway is a series of actions among molecules in a cell that leads to a certain product or a change in the cell. Enter a Pathway ID from KEGG Pathway or Reactome.

tooltip.title: Pubmed ID
tooltip.text: A PMID is the unique identifier number used in PubMed for each article. The PMID is assigned to each article record when it enters the PubMed system.

tooltip.title: Glycosylation Evidence Type
tooltip.text: Click to select Glycosylation Evidence Type.

tooltip.title: Organism
tooltip.text: An individual animal, plant, or single-celled life form. Click to select an Organism that makes your protein(s).

tooltip.title: Protein Name
tooltip.text: Protein name in a database that allows unambiguous identification of a protein. Enter the Name of your protein.

tooltip.title: Chemical Mass
tooltip.text: Molecular weight [mass] in Daltons. Use the sliders to select a Chemical Mass range for your protein(s).

tooltip.title: RefSeq Accession
tooltip.text: A distinct accession number format assigned to RefSeq record that begins with two characters followed by an underscore in the NCBI RefSeq database. Enter the RefSeq Accession of your protein.

tooltip.title: Disease Name
tooltip.text: Search for protein(s) that have been associated with a disease. Specify the disease name. A proposal system will assist in choosing the right name while typing.

tooltip.title: Disease ID
tooltip.text: Search for protein(s) that have been associated with a disease. Specify the disase using MONDO, DOID or MIM.

annotation_site.name: Annotation
annotation_site.tooltip: site annotation Information for selected Protein accession

chemical_mass.text: Find all proteins / glycoproteins with the same chemical mass.

go_id.text: Find all proteins / glycoproteins with the same GO annotation.

pathway_id.text: Find all proteins / glycoproteins with the same pathway.

disease_id.text: Find all proteins / glycoproteins with the same disease.

pmid.text: Find all proteins / glycoproteins with the same PMID.

tooltip.title: Annotation Type
tooltip.text: Click to select Annotation Type.

tooltip.title: Annotation
tooltip.text: Click to select Annotation.

tooltip.title: Position
tooltip.text: You can search site by entering annotation Position.

tooltip.title: Range
tooltip.text: You can search site by entering annotation Start Position and End Position.

tooltip.title: Position
tooltip.text: You can  enter site position to get more annotation information.

tooltip.title: Pattern
tooltip.text: You can  enter site pattern to get more annotation information.

tooltip.title: Neighbors
tooltip.text: You can search neighboring site by entering annotation information.

tooltip.title: Glycosylated Amino Acid
tooltip.text: Amino acids are organic compounds containing amine (-NH2) and carboxyl (-COOH) functional groups, along with a side chain (R group) specific to each amino acid. Click to highlight multiple selections for Glycosylated Amino Acid.

tooltip.title: Super Search Sample Query List
tooltip.text: Select sample super search query and click on search to execute. This will execute sample query and prefill the results. You can click on respective node(s) to see properties used to perform search.
Enable/Disable expert mode that allows creation of user defined JSON queries.
Switching between simple and advanced mode allows to show and hide edge specific search results.
Allows performing predefined queries to get you started with supersearch.
Remove all applied search filters and revert back to the initial overview.
Show last executed query in JSON format. Can be used in combination with Debug mode or when reporting problems.

tooltip.title: UniProtKB Accession
tooltip.text: Enter a Protein UniProtKB Accession.

tooltip.title: Sequence
tooltip.text: The sequence of the amino acids of the protein. Enter a Protein Sequence.

num_alignments.name: Number of Proteins to show in the hit sequences alignment
num_alignments.shortName: Number of Proteins to show in the hit sequences alignment

tooltip.title: Number of Proteins to show in the hit sequences alignment

question_1.text: What are the glycosyltransferases used to add the residues contained in {0} in human?

tooltip.title: Glycan X
tooltip.text: Provide the GlyTouCan Accession of a fully defined glycan in GlyGen and a list of all enzymes potentially involved in the biosynthesis will be shown. To find the GlyTouCan access for a fully defined glycan it is possible to use the GlyGen glycan search and after performing the search to filter by "Fully defined" in the left side menu.

question_2.text: Which proteins have been shown to bear {0} and which site is this glycan attached to?

tooltip.title: Glycan X
tooltip.text: Provide the GlyTouCan Accession of a glycan in GlyGen and a list of proteins and their sites that carry this glycan will be shown. To find the GlyTouCan access for a glycan it is possible to use the GlyGen glycan search.

question_3.text: What are the gene locations of the enzymes involved in the biosynthesis of {0} in human?

tooltip.title: Glycan X
tooltip.text: Provide the GlyTouCan Accession of a glycan in GlyGen and a list of all enzymes potentially involved in the biosynthesis together with their gene location will be shown. To find the GlyTouCan access for a glycan it is possible to use the GlyGen glycan search.

question_4.text: What are the orthologs of {0} in different organism?

tooltip.title: Protein X
tooltip.text: Provide the UniProt Accession of a protein in GlyGen (e.g., P14210 for HGF) to find the orthologs of this protein in different organism present in GlyGen. To find the UniProt Accession for a protein it is possible to use the GlyGen protein search.

tooltip.title: Protein X
tooltip.text: Provide the UniProt Accession of a protein in GlyGen (e.g., P14210 for HGF) to see all the function annotations of this protein in GlyGen. To find the UniProt Accession for a protein it is possible to use the GlyGen protein search.

question_6.text: Which glycans might have been synthesized in mouse using {0}?

tooltip.title: Enzyme X
tooltip.text: Provide the UniProt Accession of a enzyme in GlyGen (e.g., P15291 for B4GALT1) to see all glycans whos synthesis may have involved the enzyme. To find the UniProt Accession for a protein/enzyme it is possible to use the GlyGen protein search.

question_7.text: Where are the N-Glycosylation Sequons of the {0}?

tooltip.title: Protein X
tooltip.text: Provide the UniProt Accession of a protein in GlyGen (e.g., P14210 for HGF) to see all N-glycosylation sequons of the protein. To find the UniProt Accession for a protein it is possible to use the GlyGen protein search.

tooltip.title: Organism
tooltip.text: Select a species to see the glycosyltransferases report for this species in GlyGen.

tooltip.title: Organism
tooltip.text: Select a species to see the glycosylhydrolases report for this species in GlyGen.

question_10.text: What are the reported or predicted glycosylated proteins in {0}?

tooltip.title: Organism
tooltip.text: Select a species to see all glycosylated proteins reported for this species in GlyGen. It is possible to filter this list using the "Type" field and show sites reported in papers (reported), sites prediced using prediction software (predicted) or the combined list (both).

question_11.text: Which glycosyltransferases are known to be involved in {0}?

tooltip.title: Disease
tooltip.text: Provide a disease name to see the list of glycosyltransferases that have been report to be involved in or affected by this disease. Its possible to start typing and the system will propose similar disease names in GlyGen. It is also possible to search for disease names using the Disease Ontology.

question_tryMe1.text: What are the glycosyltransferases used to add  the residues contained in the lipid-linked N-glycan precursor GlcNAc2Man9Glc3 ({0}) in human?

question_tryMe2.text: Which proteins have been shown to bear a bi-antennary fully sialylated N-Glycan ({0}) and which site is this glycan attached to?

question_tryMe3.text: Which glycans might have been synthesized in mouse using Mgat1 ({0})?

errors.contactUsMsg: If the problem persists then you may

networkError.title: Network Error
networkError.message: Oops, something went wrong. Please try again later.

0.title: Not Connected
0.message: Could not connect to the server.

101.title: Server Not Found
101.message: Could not connect to the server.

500.title: Server Error
500.message: An Internal server error occured. We are doing our best to resolve it.

404.title: Server Not Found
404.message: Could not connect to the server.

unexpected-field-in-query.title: Unexpected Field Input Error
unexpected-field-in-query.message: This is an unexpected field input. Please try again.

invalid-query-json.title: Invalid Input Error
invalid-query-json.message: This is not a valid input. Please try again.

open-connection-failed.title: Unexpected Error
open-connection-failed.message: Sorry, we couldn't connect to database.

invalid-parameter-value-length.title: Missing Input Value
invalid-parameter-value-length.message: Please input a value and try again.

no-search-criteria-submitted.title: Unexpected Error
no-search-criteria-submitted.message: Input error occurred. Please provide input a term to search for.

no-result-found.title: no-result-found
no-result-found.message: Input error occurred. Please provide input a term to search for.

timeout.title: TimeOut Error
timeout.message: Sorry, the server didn't respond. Please try again later.

abort.title: Request Aborted
abort.message: Sorry, your requested was aborted. Please try again.

parsererror.title: Parsing Error
parsererror.message: There was an error in the data received. We are looking into it.

js_error.title: Website Error
js_error.message: Oops, there seems to be some issue on this page. Sorry, for the inconvenience. We've recorded this issue and are looking into it.

defaultDialogAlert.title: Unexpected Error
defaultDialogAlert.message: Oops, something went wrong. Please try again later.

compSerarchError.title: Composition Search Error - No Results Found
compSerarchError.message: Sorry, we couldn't find any data matching your input. Please change your search term and try again.

simpleSerarchError.message: Sorry, we couldn't find any data matching your input. Please change your search term and try again.

quickSerarchError.title: Quick Search Error - No Results Found

tryMeSerarchError.title: Try Me Search Error - No Results Found
tryMeSerarchError.message: Sorry, we couldn't find any data matching your input. Please try again after some time.

idMappingError.title: ID Mapping Error - No Results Found
idMappingError.message: Sorry, we couldn't find any data matching your input. Please change your search term and try again.

superSearchError.title: Super Search Error - Enter Valid Input
superSearchError.message: Sorry, we couldn't process search request. Please enter valid input.

blastSearchError.title: Blast Search Error - No Results Found

blastSearchUniProtAccError.title: Blast Search Error - Enter Valid UniProtKB Accession

bad characters in protein sequence.message: There are non amino acid characters in the search sequence. Please change your search term and try again.

tooltip.text: If Glycan is selected then whole id mapping will be related to glycan. Same for protein/glycoprotein.
